topics.title: What Community Notes is and why it works
topics.summary: Keith and Jay explain Community Notes: users propose context notes on misleading posts, others rate them, and notes show only when found helpful by people who typically disagree—driving neutrality and accuracy.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the guests and frames Community Notes as a uniquely impactful product, previewing topics like origins, algorithm design, principles, and adoption by other platforms.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for WorkOS and Productboard, covering enterprise auth/authorization tooling and product management platform capabilities.

topics.title: Community Notes mechanics and bridging agreement algorithm
topics.summary: They clarify that notes don’t appear instantly or by simple majority vote; instead, a bridging-based approach looks for agreement among historically disagreeing raters to resist bias and manipulation.

topics.title: Examples, context vs fact-checking, and openness
topics.summary: They walk through common examples (AI/out-of-context media), emphasize that Notes add context rather than act as definitive fact-checks, and explain the principle of openness—regular people, not curated experts.

topics.title: Eligibility, contributor onboarding, and earning write access
topics.summary: Any post can be noted (including leaders, advertisers, and Elon), but only contributors who earn reputation through helpful ratings can write notes; Lenny shares his own contributor experience.

topics.title: Scale metrics, media matching, and notification UX
topics.summary: They share growth stats (notes/day, views, contributor count), explain matching notes across identical media/URLs for scale, and discuss notifying users who previously engaged with a post once it’s noted.

topics.title: Thresholds, conservatism, and note quality controls
topics.summary: Jay describes the scoring threshold (an internal scale) and additional filters (e.g., incorrect-tag agreement), while Keith explains why the system is intentionally conservative to protect trust and quality.

topics.title: How many notes show and handling polarized raters
topics.summary: Only ~7–11% of proposed notes are shown; they explain demotion of unreliable raters, why some true notes may not bridge polarized groups, and the philosophy of including all viewpoints to model humanity.

topics.title: Volunteer motivation and real-world influence
topics.summary: They stress contributors are unpaid volunteers motivated by impact, highlighting examples like a note prompting the White House to delete and reissue a tweet—showing how small accounts can shape discourse.

topics.title: Behavioral impact: engagement drops and deletions
topics.summary: They discuss experimental and external research showing large reductions in likes/reposts when notes appear (30–40% in A/B tests; 50–60% overall repost drops) and increased post deletions after being noted.

topics.title: Origin story: why Keith started the project
topics.summary: Keith recounts joining Twitter in 2016 amid election discourse, recognizing misinformation as a critical unsolved problem, and later stepping away from managing a large PM org to pursue a high-impact solution.

topics.title: Twitter era context and renaming Birdwatch to Community Notes
topics.summary: They place the project in the Jack Dorsey turnaround era, then describe how Elon praised the feature post-acquisition and quickly reverted the name from Birdwatch to the clearer 'Community Notes.'

topics.title: Small-team leadership, impact, and the Thermal model
topics.summary: Keith shares advice on stepping off the management track to maximize impact, then explains 'Thermal'—a protected, highly focused team structure with direct senior decision-making, fast iteration, and minimal bureaucracy.

topics.title: Early engineering approach and algorithm evolution setup
topics.summary: Jay outlines early algorithm iterations (anti-manipulation PageRank-like approach) and the pivot toward bridging-based methods, including pulling in more engineers via a bake-off/competition to refine the solution.
